title: Value of a definite integral from a Riemann sum

content.question: For a certain continuous function f, the right Riemann sum approximation of <math> <semantics> <mrow> <mstyle displaystyle="true"> <mrow> <msubsup> <mo>∫</mo> <mn>0</mn> <mn>2</mn> </msubsup> <mi>f</mi> </mrow> </mstyle> <mrow> <mo>(</mo> <mi>x</mi> <mo>)</mo> </mrow> <mtext> </mtext> <mi>d</mi> <mi>x</mi> </mrow> <annotation encoding="MathType-MTEF">MathType@MTEF@5@5@@433A@</annotation> </semantics> </math> with n subintervals of equal length is <math> <semantics> <mrow> <mfrac> <mrow> <mn>2</mn> <mrow> <mo>(</mo> <mrow> <mi>n</mi> <mo>+</mo> <mn>1</mn> </mrow> <mo>)</mo> </mrow> <mrow> <mo>(</mo> <mrow> <mn>3</mn> <mi>n</mi> <mo>+</mo> <mn>2</mn> </mrow> <mo>)</mo> </mrow> </mrow> <mrow> <msup> <mi>n</mi> <mn>2</mn> </msup> </mrow> </mfrac> </mrow> <annotation encoding="MathType-MTEF">MathType@MTEF@5@5@@454E@</annotation> </semantics> </math> for all n. What is the value of <math> <semantics> <mrow> <mstyle displaystyle="true"> <mrow> <msubsup> <mo>∫</mo> <mn>0</mn> <mn>2</mn> </msubsup> <mi>f</mi> </mrow> </mstyle> <mrow> <mo>(</mo> <mi>x</mi> <mo>)</mo> </mrow> <mtext> </mtext> <mi>d</mi> <mi>x</mi> </mrow> <annotation encoding="MathType-MTEF">MathType@MTEF@5@5@@433A@</annotation> </semantics> </math>?

topic.text: 6.3: Riemann Sums, Summation Notation, and Definite Integral Notation

skill.text: Skill 2.C: Identify a re-expression of mathematical information presented in a given representation
